revision.text:
{{ infobox nobility | name = Louis Henry, Prince of Nassau-Dillenburg | image = Lodewijk Hendrik van Nassau-Dillenburg, after Anthony van Dyck.jpg | caption = Louis Henry, Prince of Nassau-Dillenburg ([[Pieter Philippe]]) | noble family = [[House of Nassau]] | father = [[George, Count of Nassau-Dillenburg]] | mother = Anna Amalia of Nassau-Saarbrücken | spouse = Catherine of Sayn-Wittgenstein
Elisabeth of Salm-Dhaun
Sofie Magdalene of Nassau-Hadamar | birth_date = {{birth_date|1594|5|9|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Saarbrücken]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1662|7|12|1594|5|9|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Dillenburg]] }} '''Louis Henry of Nassau-Dillenburg''' (9 May 1594 in [[Saarbrücken]] – 12 July 1662 in [[Dillenburg]]), was Count, and from 1654 [[Prince]] of [[Nassau-Dillenburg]]. During the [[Thirty Years' War]], he was a senior officer. He climbed to the rank of [[Major General]]. Before 1635, he served on the [[Protestant]] side; after 1635, he served in the imperial army. == Background == He was the son of the Count [[George, Count of Nassau-Dillenburg|George]] of Nassau-Beilstein and later Nassau-Dillenburg. His mother was Anna Amalie Countess of [[Nassau-Saarbrücken]]. In 1616, he married in his first marriage Countess Catherine of [[Sayn-Wittgenstein]] (1588–1651). In 1653 he married his second wife Wild- and [[Rhinegrave|Rhinegravine]] Elizabeth of Salm-Dhaun (1593–1656). In 1656, he married his third wife, Sofie Magdalene of Nassau-Hadamar (1622–1658). He had five sons and eight daughters from his first marriage, two of the sons and four of the daughters died early. From his second marriage, he had another three sons, two of whom died early. == Early years == Louis Henry was first educated at the court in Dillenburg and later at [[Herborn Academy]]. He then made a [[Grand Tour]] to [[France]] and the [[Netherlands]]. He received his military training under Prince [[Maurice of Nassau, Prince of Orange|Maurice of Orange-Nassau]]. As early as 1614, he participated in the relief of [[Emmerich am Rhein|Emmerich]], which was besieged by the Spanish. Louis Henry and his brother [[Albert, Count of Nassau-Dillenburg|Albert]] inherited Nassau-Dillenburg in 1623. They ruled jointly, until Albert died in 1626 and Louis Henry became the sole ruler. == Councillor Hoen and domestic policies == The Emperor had [[outlaw]]ed the Counts of Nassau-Dillenburg and Nassau-Hadamar for allegedly supporting Elector Palatine [[Frederick V, Elector Palatine|Frederick V]]. The Emperor had assigned their possessions to [[John VIII, Count of Nassau-Siegen|John VIII]] of Nassau-Siegen. This ruling was never carried out, thanks to the efforts of [[John Louis of Nassau-Hadamar|John Louis]] of Nassau-Hadamar. Even so, the military occupation of Nassau-Dillenburg from 1622 onwards, put a high strain on his land. Louis Henry saw reducing this damage as his main task. He only played a relatively small rôle himself. Policies were mainly drawn up and carried out by his councillor, the publicist and professor [[Philipp Heinrich Hoen]] (''Hoenosius''). Hoen also administered the county during Henry Louis long periods of absence. He also represented the interests of the House of Nassau and the [[Wetterau Association of Imperial Counts]] in the negotiations the led to the [[Peace of Westphalia]]. == In Protestant service == Louis Henry initially stood on the side of the [[Protestant Union]]. He joined the army of King [[Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden]] as a colonel. He led an infantry regiment and later a cavalry regiment. His troops distinguished themselves in various battles, and Louis Henry himself showed personal bravery. He distringuished himself in particular during the storming of fortified cities and fortresses, such as the capture of [[Braunfels]] in 1635. == In the imperial service == Later that year, when the war seemed to turn against the Swedes, Louis Henry changed sides and joined the imperial side. He served the emperor as a senior officer and united his forces with those of Landgrave [[George II, Landgrave of Hesse-Darmstadt|George II]] of Hesse-Darmstadt. In 1637, he held the rank of [[Major general]] and marched into Saxony. He then enjoyed the imperial favour at the court in [[Prague]]. In 1654, he was rewarded for his services by being raised to [[Imperial Prince]]. == Domestic policies after 1649 == After Hoen died in 1649, Louis Henry tried to enforce an [[Absolutism (European history)|absolutist]] policy in Dillenburg. He was only partially successful. He also attempted to support [[Herborn Academy]], which had been badly affected by the war, but eventually lost interest. Louis Henry died in 1662. Since his eldest son, [[George Louis, Prince of Nassau-Dillenburg|George Louis]] had already died in 1656, Dillenburg was inherited by his grandson [[Henry, Prince of Nassau-Dillenburg|Henry]]. == Family == Louis Henry was married three times. His first wife was Catherine of Sayn-Wittgenstein (1588–1651), the daughter of [[Louis I, Count of Sayn-Wittgenstein]]. The couple had the following children: * Anne (1616–1649), married: *# in 1638 with Count Philip of Wied (d. 1638) *# in 1646 with Count Christian of San-Wittgenstein (d. 1675) * [[George Louis, Prince of Nassau-Dillenburg|George Louis]] (1618–1656), Hereditary Prince of Nassau-Dillenburg, married in 1638 with Augusta Anna, the daughter of Count [[Henry Julius, Duke of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel|Henry Julius]] of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel * Elisabeth (1619–1665) * Juliana (1620–1622) * Albert (1621–1622) * Catherine (1622–1631) * Louise (1623–1665), married in 1646 John Louis of Isenburg-Büdingen (d. 1685) * Unnamed daughter (1624) * Henry (1626–1627) * Magdalena (1628–1663), married in 1662 with Christian Maurice of Isenburg-Büdingen (d. 1664) * [[Adolph, Prince of Nassau-Schaumburg|Adolph]] (1629–1676), Prince of Nassau-Schaumburg, married in 1653 with Charlotte (1640–1707), the daughter of Count [[Peter Melander Graf von Holzappel|Peter Melander of Holzappel]] * Philip (1630–1657) * Zwillige (1631) * Maria Eleonora (1632–1633) After Catherine's death, he married Wild- and Rhinegravine Elizabeth of Salm-Dhaun (1593–1656), the daughter of Wild- and [[Rhinegrave]] Adolph Henry of Dhaun-Neufviller. However, she died soon after the wedding. In 1656, he married his third wife. She was Sophie of Nassau-Hadamar (1622–1658), the daughter of [[John Louis of Nassau-Hadamar|John Louis]] of Nassau-Hadamar. They had three children: * Augustus (1657–1680) * Charles (1658–1659) * Louis (1658-1658) == Ancestors == {{ahnentafel top|width=100%}} {{ahnentafel-compact5 |style=font-size: 90%; line-height: 110%; |border=1 |boxstyle=padding-top: 0; padding-bottom: 0; |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; | 1= 1. '''Louis Henry, Prince of Nassau-Dillenburg''' | 2= 2. [[George, Count of Nassau-Dillenburg]] | 3= 3. Anna Amalia of Nassau-Saarbrücken | 4= 4. [[John VI, Count of Nassau-Dillenburg]] | 5= 5. [[Elisabeth of Leuchtenberg]] | 6= 6. [[Philip IV, Count of Nassau-Weilburg]] | 7= 7. Erika of Manderscheid-Blankenheim | 8= 8. [[William I of Nassau-Dillenburg]] | 9= 9. [[Juliana of Stolberg]] | 10= 10. [[George III, Landgrave of Leuchtenberg]] | 11= 11. [[Barbara of Brandenburg-Ansbach-Kulmbach]] | 12= 12. [[Philip III, Count of Nassau-Weilburg]] | 13= 13. Amalie of Isenburg-Büdingen | 14= 14. Francis of Manderscheid-Schleiden-Virneburg | 15= 15. Anna of Isenburg-Neumagen | 16= 16. [[John V of Nassau-Dillenburg]] | 17= 17. [[Elisabeth of Hesse-Marburg]] | 18= 18. [[Bodo VIII, Count of Stolberg-Wernigerode]] | 19= 19. [[Anna of Eppstein-Königstein]] | 20= 20. [[John IV, Landgrave of Leuchtenberg]] | 21= 21. Margaret of Schwarzburg | 22= 22. [[Frederick I, Margrave of Brandenburg-Ansbach]] | 23= 23. [[Sophia Jagiellon, Margravine of Brandenburg-Ansbach]] | 24= 24. Dietrich IV of Manderscheid-Schleiden | 29= 29. Elisabeth of Neufchâtel | 30= 30. Salentin VII of Isenburg-Neumagen | 31= 31. Elisabeth of Hunolstein-Neumagen }} {{ahnentafel bottom}} == References == * {{NDB|15|403|404|Ludwig Heinrich von Nassau-Dillenburg|Gerhard Menk}} * {{De-ADB|19|566|567|Ludwig Heinrich von Nassau-Dillenburg|Ernst Joachim|ADB:Ludwig Heinrich}} {{Authority control}} == External links == * http://www.royaltyguide.nl/families/nassau/nassaudillenburg3.htm {{S-start}} {{S-hou|[[House of Nassau]]|9 May|1594|12 July|1662}} {{S-bef|before=[[George, Count of Nassau-Dillenburg|George]]|as=Count of Nassau-Dillenburg}} {{S-ttl|title=[[Nassau-Dillenburg|Prince of Nassau-Dillenburg]]
